content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

```
function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump::Int=3)
    return dt + Dates.Hour(bump)
end
```
This function takes a `dt` (timestamp) of type `DateTime` and a `bump` (defaults to 3 hours) of type `Int`. It returns the timestamp with the specified bump added, also of type `DateTime`. If the input `dt` is not of type `DateTime`, it will throw an error.

For example, if we call `timezone_bumper(now(), 4)`, it will return a new timestamp that is 4 hours ahead of the current time.
```
julia> timezone_bumper(now(), 4)
2023-02-28T15:59:17.874
```
Note that we can also pass an optional argument `bump` to specify the number of hours to bump by. If not specified, it defaults to 3 hours.
